chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Deep vein thrombosis - prevention for travellers
chapter.summary: Covers assessing the risk of, and preventing, venous thromboembolism (deep vein thrombosis and/or pulmonary embolism) in people travelling long distances.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess DVT risk in travellers?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Assessment should be made on an individual basis as the relative risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) may change over time. 
  • Take into account the planned duration of travel and any pre-existing risk factors for DVT. 
  • People are at:
    • High risk of travel-related DVT if they have:
      • An active malignancy. 
      • Undergone recent major surgery (within the previous 4 weeks).
      • Had a previous unprovoked venous thromboembolism (VTE).
      • Had a previous travel-related DVT with no associated temporary risk factor. 
      • More than one risk factor for DVT.
    • Moderate risk if they have a risk factor and are not considered at high risk.
    • Low risk if they have no pre-existing risk factors.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Prevention and management of venous thromboembolism [SIGN, 2014], the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) health information for travellers The yellow book: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism [CDC, 2017], the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines on travel-related venous thrombosis [Watson and Baglin, 2011] and expert opinion in a consensus statement Traveller's thrombosis: International consensus statement [Schobersberger et al, 2008].

Assessment of risks
  • The duration of travel and pre-existing risk factors for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) should be taken into account when assessing the risk of DVT in travellers, as the risk of travel-related thrombosis is higher in individuals with pre-existing risk factors for the development for venous thromboembolism (VTE), and travel of 3 hours and over is associated with a thrombotic risk [Watson and Baglin, 2011].  
  • The risk of symptomatic venous thrombosis after air travel is moderately increased on average, and rises with increasing exposure and in high-risk groups [Kuipers et al, 2007]. 
  • The risk of VTE is increased after longer journeys [Schobersberger et al, 2008]. 
    • There is a four-fold increase in risk for air-travel over 8 hours and the risk increases markedly for journeys in excess of 12 hours. 
Risk stratification
  • An international consensus statement proposed three levels of risk (low, medium, or high) for travel-related DVT based on the presence or absence of pre-disposing factors [Schobersberger et al, 2008]. 
  • The BCSH guideline states that it is likely that recent major surgery (within 1 month), active malignancy, previous unprovoked VTE, previous travel-related VTE with no associated temporary risk factor or presence of more than one risk factor identifies those travellers at highest thrombosis risk [Watson and Baglin, 2011]. 
  • VTE is a multicausal disorder and the accumulation of risk factors added to an individual’s inherent thrombotic risk determines whether or not thrombosis develops [Watson and Baglin, 2011]. 
  • The recommendation that somebody who has a risk factor, but is not at high risk, is considered at moderate risk is pragmatic and based on what CKS considers good clinical practice.
    • Clinical judgement should be used to determine the risk of travel-related DVT based on travel duration and the presence of any risk factors.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give someone who is at low risk of travel-related DVT?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For people assessed as having a relatively low risk of developing travel-related deep vein thrombosis (DVT):
    • Provide advice on general measures to reduce the risk of travel-related DVT.
    • Reassure the person that no specific treatment is required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines on travel-related venous thrombosis [Watson and Baglin, 2011], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) health information for travellers The yellow book: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism [CDC, 2017], expert opinion in a consensus statement Traveller's thrombosis: International consensus statement [Schobersberger et al, 2008], and what CKS considers good clinical practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give someone who is at moderate risk of travel-related DVT?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For people at moderate risk of developing travel-related deep vein thrombosis (DVT):
    • Provide advice on general measures to reduce the risk of travel-related DVT.
    • Advise the person to use graduated compression stockings providing 15–30 mm Hg of pressure at the ankle.
      • Class 1 stockings (exerting a pressure of 14–17 mmHg at the ankle) or proprietary flight socks may be sufficient. 
      • Measure the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) in both legs using a Doppler machine if the person has symptoms of arterial disease. If the ABPI is less than 0.8, compression stockings are contraindicated. For further information, see CKS topic on Compression stockings.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines on travel-related venous thrombosis [Watson and Baglin, 2011], the American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) guideline Prevention of VTE in nonsurgical patients [Kahn, 2012], expert opinion in a consensus statement Traveller's thrombosis: International consensus statement [Schobersberger et al, 2008], the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) health information for travellers The yellow book: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism [CDC, 2017], a Cochrane systematic review Compression stockings for preventing deep vein thrombosis in airline passengers [Clark, 2016], and a randomized controlled trial Frequency and prevention of symptomless deep-vein thrombosis in long-haul flights [Scurr et al, 2001].  

Graduated compression stockings (GCS)
  • A Cochrane systematic review of 11 randomized controlled trials (n = 2,905) which assessed the effects of wearing compression stockings versus not wearing them for preventing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in people travelling on flights lasting at least four hours, found that there was high-quality evidence that compression stockings reduced the incidence of symptomless DVT [Clark, 2016]. 
    • In the nine trials (n = 2,821) which compared wearing graduated compression stockings on both legs versus not wearing them the compression strengths in the trials ranged from 10–30 mm Hg.
  • Graduated compression stockings (GCS) are indicated for long-distance travellers at increased risk of DVT. GCS appear to reduce asymptomatic DVT in travellers and are generally well tolerated [CDC, 2017]. 
    • CDC and ACCP recommend using below-knee GCS providing 15–30 mm Hg of pressure at the ankle for people at increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE).
  • The use of anti-embolism stockings for prevention of VTE during and after long-haul travel is not routinely recommended [SIGN, 2014].
  • There are limited data suggesting a reduction in subclinical events using class 1 stockings [SIGN, 2014]. 
    • In a randomized controlled trial (RCT) which compared the use of class 1 below-knee graduated compression stockings with no stockings in airline passengers over 50 years of age with no history of thromboembolic problems where all the passengers made journeys lasting more than 8 hours per flight [Scurr et al, 2001]: 
      • Twelve people in the control group (n = 100) developed asymptomatic DVT in the lower limbs (assessed using duplex ultrasonography within 48 hours of the return flight) and nobody in the stocking group (n = 100) developed asymptomatic DVT (relative risk 0.04, 95% CI 0 to 0.6).
      • Four people in the stocking group developed superficial thrombophlebitis while none were found in the control group.
  • CKS could find no studies which compared different strengths of stockings.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give someone who is at high risk of travel-related DVT?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For people assessed at high risk of developing travel-related deep vein thrombosis (DVT):
    • Assess the person's suitability for long distance travel. If appropriate:
      • Consider seeking specialist advice, or
      • Recommend delaying or cancelling the trip (for example, people should postpone long-haul flights for 3 months after a hip or knee replacement).
  • If long distance travel is unavoidable:
    • Provide advice on general measures to reduce the risk of travel-related DVT.
    • Advise the use of graduated compression stockings providing 15-30 mm Hg of pressure at the ankle.
      • Class 1 stockings (exerting a pressure of 14–17 mmHg at the ankle) or proprietary flight socks may be sufficient. 
      • Measure the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) in both legs using a Doppler machine if the person has symptoms of arterial disease. If the ABPI is less than 0.8, compression stockings are contraindicated.
    • Seek specialist advice depending on local pathways regarding whether the use of low molecular weight heparin is indicated.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Low molecular weight heparin
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is prescribed:
    • Ensure that appropriate arrangements are in place for LMWH administration (for example, that a nurse is available) or that the person is given training if the drug will be self-administered.
      • LMWH should be administered before departure.
    • Prescribe sufficient LMWH to cover the outgoing and any subsequent connecting or return flights.
    • Prescribe LMWH as pre-filled syringes for ease of administration.
    • Provide the person with a letter that explains why they have to carry needles and syringes while travelling, to show to security, immigration, and customs officials.
    • Warn about the increased risk of bleeding and bruising.
    • Advise the person to seek urgent medical advice if there is uncontrolled or excessive bleeding or bruising, or if they have a sudden severe headache (possible intracranial haemorrhage), or gastrointestinal pains (signifying possible gastrointestinal bleeding).
    • Give advice on the safe storage and disposal of needles and syringes ('sharps').

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines on travel-related venous thrombosis [Watson and Baglin, 2011], the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Prevention and management of venous thromboembolism [SIGN, 2014], the American College of Chest Physicians (ACCP) guideline Prevention of VTE in nonsurgical patients: antithrombotic therapy and prevention of thrombosis [Kahn, 2012], expert opinion in a consensus statement Traveller's thrombosis: International consensus statement [Schobersberger et al, 2008], the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) health information for travellers The yellow book: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism [CDC, 2017], a Cochrane systematic review Compression stockings for preventing deep vein thrombosis in airline passengers [Clark, 2016], and a randomized controlled trial Frequency and prevention of symptomless deep-vein thrombosis in long-haul flights [Scurr et al, 2001]. 

Graduated compression stockings (GCS)
  • A Cochrane systematic review of 11 randomized controlled trials (n = 2,905) which assessed the effects of wearing compression stockings versus not wearing them for preventing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in people travelling on flights lasting at least four hours, found that there was high-quality evidence that compression stockings reduced the incidence of symptomless DVT [Clark, 2016]. 
    • In the nine trials (n = 2,821) which compared wearing graduated compression stockings on both legs versus not wearing them, the compression strengths in the trials ranged from 10–30 mm Hg.
  • Graduated compression stockings (GCS) are indicated for long-distance travellers at increased risk of DVT. GCS appear to reduce asymptomatic DVT in travellers and are generally well tolerated [CDC, 2017]. 
    • CDC and ACCP recommend using below-knee GCS providing 15–30 mm Hg of pressure at the ankle for people at increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE).
  • The use of anti-embolism stockings for prevention of VTE during and after long-haul travel is not routinely recommended [SIGN, 2014].
  • There are limited data suggesting a reduction in subclinical events using class 1 stockings [SIGN, 2014]. 
    • In a randomized controlled trial (RCT) which compared the use of class 1 below-knee graduated compression stockings with no stockings in airline passengers over 50 years of age with no history of thromboembolic problems where all the passengers made journeys lasting more than 8 hours per flight [Scurr et al, 2001]: 
      • Twelve people in the control group (n = 100) developed asymptomatic DVT in the lower limbs (assessed using duplex ultrasonography within 48 hours of the return flight) and nobody in the stocking group (n = 100) developed asymptomatic DVT (relative risk 0.04, 95% CI 0 to 0.6).
      • Four people in the stocking group developed superficial thrombophlebitis while none were found in the control group.
  • CKS could find no studies which compared different strengths of stockings.
Prophylaxis with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)
  • In people deemed to be at especially high risk of travel-related VTE, prophylactic LMWH administered as a single dose subcutaneously on the day of travel could be considered [SIGN, 2014]. 
    • However, there are no data from randomised trials on the use of pharmacological prophylaxis for the prevention of travel-related VTE.
  • The CDC only recommends anticoagulant prophylaxis in people who are at high-risk and when the potential benefits outweigh the risks [CDC, 2017]. 
Seeking specialist advice before prescribing LMWH
  • CKS recommends seeking specialist advice before prescribing LMWH because the use of LMWH for the prevention of travel-related DVT is unlicensed, there is lack of evidence about benefit, and CKS found no clear guidance on the prescribing of LMWH (for example choice of preparation, dosage, time of administration, and duration of treatment) in high risk people, particularly if other risk factors are present (for example people with cancer).
Prescribing LMWH
  • The recommendations on prescribing LMWH are pragmatic and what CKS considers good clinical practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What general advice should I give to all long distance travellers?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Offer reassurance that the risk of travel-related deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is very low in healthy people without risk factors. 
  • Advise the person to:
    • Avoid long periods of immobility. Walk around regularly — for example, a regular trip to the bathroom every 2–3 hours. 
    • Choose an aisle seat when feasible.
    • Perform frequent calf muscle exercises.
    • Ensure hand luggage is not placed somewhere that it restricts movement of legs and feet. 
    • Wear clothing that is comfortable and loose. 
    • Avoid the use of tranquilisers, or sleeping tablets. 
    • Maintain a normal fluid intake (at least 250 ml every 2 hours) and avoid excessive alcohol consumption. 
  • Seek urgent medical advice (for example, from a local doctor or the nearest Accident and Emergency department) if they develop the following after the trip:
    • Swollen, painful legs, especially where one is more affected than the other, and/or
    • Breathing difficulties (suggesting pulmonary embolism).
    • For more information on symptoms, see the CKS topic Deep vein thrombosis. 
  • Obtain adequate medical insurance before they travel.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Prevention and management of venous thromboembolism [SIGN, 2014], the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) health information for travellers The yellow book: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism [CDC, 2017], the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines on travel-related venous thrombosis [Watson and Baglin, 2011], expert opinion in a consensus statement Traveller's thrombosis: International consensus statement [Schobersberger et al, 2008] and the World Health Organization (WHO) document International travel and health [WHO, 2012]. 

Reducing immobility
  • In view of the role of venous stasis in the pathogenesis of travel-related venous thromboembolism (VTE), it is reasonable to recommend frequent ambulation and calf muscle exercises for long-distance travellers [CDC, 2017].  
  • Exercise of the calf muscles can stimulate the circulation, alleviate discomfort, fatigue and stiffness, and may reduce the risk of developing DVT [WHO, 2012]. 
  • Although there is no evidence to demonstrate that measures to increase mobility can reduce the risk of travel-related deep vein thrombosis (DVT), maintaining mobility is a reasonable precaution for all travellers of journeys over 3 hours, given that long periods of immobility may predispose to DVT [Watson and Baglin, 2011]. 
Fluid intake
  • Haemoconcentration increases blood viscosity and reduces blood flow, especially in the deep veins of the leg in immobile patients. Adequate hydration should be ensured in immobilised patients [SIGN, 2014]. 
  • However, the advice to maintain a normal fluid intake in travellers is pragmatic, as there is there is no evidence to support an association between dehydration and the development of VTE [Watson and Baglin, 2011], and no direct evidence that drinking plenty of non–alcoholic beverages to ensure adequate hydration or avoiding alcoholic beverages has a protective effect. While maintaining hydration is reasonable and unlikely to cause harm, it cannot be recommended specifically to prevent travel-related VTE [CDC, 2017]. 
Aisle seats
  • Compared with aisle seats, window seats in one study were reported to increase the general risk of VTE by 2-fold. Aisle seats are reported to have a protective effect, compared with window or middle seats, probably because travellers are freer to move around [CDC, 2017]. 
Seek urgent medical advice
  • The recommendation to advise people to seek urgent medical advice if symptoms of DVT develop after a flight is what CKS consider good clinical practice.
Travel insurance
  • The WHO recommends that all travellers should be strongly advised to seek comprehensive travel insurance [WHO, 2012].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a joint replacement or fracture?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For people who have had a hip or knee replacement:
    • Advise them to postpone long-haul flights until 3 months after surgery as there may be an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis.
    • Advise them that it may be possible to undertake short-haul flights 6 weeks after surgery.
  • For people with a fracture in a plaster cast:
    • Advise people that airlines usually restrict air travel on short flights (less than 2 hours) for the first 24 hours after a cast has been fitted, and for 48 hours for longer flights (over 2 hours).
    • If air travel is essential before these limits, airlines usually require the cast to be split along its full length before travel.
      • Arrangements should be made to have the cast replaced once at the destination.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Civil Aviation Authority (CCA) guidance Surgical conditions: information for health professionals on assessing fitness to fly [CAA, 2018], and an NHS patient information leaflet Hip replacement Your enhanced recovery programme [NHS, 2018]. 

Air travel after joint replacement
  • Joint replacement surgery is a risk factor for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and people who have undergone joint replacement surgery are advised to avoid air travel for the first 3 months after surgery [CAA, 2018].  
  • An NHS patient information leaflet advises that people wait at least 6 weeks following surgery for a short flight (4 hours and under) and at least 12 weeks following surgery for a long haul flight (4 hours and above) [NHS, 2018]. 
  • However, CKS could find no evidence-based guidelines on airline travel in the early postoperative period, and there is a lack of evidence to support these recommendations.
  • Two studies have suggested that the risk of symptomatic venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the early postoperative period following elective total hip and knee arthroplasty is not increased. 
    • A retrospective cohort study of 1,465 consecutive primary total hip and knee arthroplasties performed over an 18-month period, which consisted of a study population of 220 patients (15.0%) who flew home at a mean of 2.9 days after surgery (range, 1–10 days) and a control population of 1,245 patients (85.0%) who did not fly during this time found that the differences in the rates of DVT, pulmonary embolism (PE), or VTE were not statistically significant between the two groups [Cooper, 2014]. 
    • In another cohort study, in which 652 patients travelled an average 1,377 miles (range, 200-8,000 miles) at an average of 6.5 days after surgery (range, 2-46 days) found that travel within 6 weeks of hip arthroplasty surgery was associated with a low rate of symptomatic DVT, with no known PEs and no deaths, and concluded that as long as patients are adequately protected from chemoprophylaxis they remain at a sufficiently low risk to make travel safe [Ball, 2007]. 
  • CKS considers that decisions on early air travel for people after joint replacement surgery should be made on an individual basis with the person, taking into account the possible associated risks. 
Air travel with a plaster cast
  • Due to the risk that swelling inside a cast can affect the circulation, many airlines restrict flying during the first 24–48 hours after a cast has been fitted. If travel is essential before these limits, airlines usually require the cast to be split along its full length as any swelling will not then affect the circulation [CAA, 2018].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a recent deep vein thrombosis planning long-haul travel?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the person has a new diagnosis (within 2 weeks) of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism, seek specialist advice.
  • If the person has been taking anticoagulants for 2 weeks or more:
    • Reassure them that they are at low-risk of developing a further thrombosis.
    • Provide advice on general measures to reduce the risk of travel-related DVT.
    • Consider prescribing graduated compression stockings.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Risk of venous thrombosis and long distance travel (including air flights): information for travelers [British Committee for Standards in Haematology, 2005] and what CKS considers good clinical practice. 

  • Patients with a recent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) who are on anticoagulant treatment are at low risk of further clots, but advice should be taken if flying within 2 weeks of a new DVT or PE [British Committee for Standards in Haematology, 2005].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give about graduated compression stockings?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Graduated compression stockings are not available on prescription for the sole indication of preventing travel-related DVT. However, they can be prescribed for people with the following indications:
    • Class 1 stockings (compression at the ankle 14–17 mmHg) for:
      • Superficial or early varicose veins.
      • Varicose veins during pregnancy.
    • Class 2 stockings (compression at the ankle 18–24 mmHg) for:
      • Varicose veins of medium severity.
      • Treatment and prevention of recurrence of leg ulcers.
      • Mild oedema.
      • Varicose veins during pregnancy.
    • Class 3 stockings (compression at the ankle 25–35 mmHg) for:
      • Gross varicose veins.
      • Post-thrombotic venous insufficiency.
      • Gross oedema.
      • Treatment and prevention of recurrence of leg ulcers.
    • For people who require a pair of class 1 graduated compression stockings (with a cost of two prescription charges) who are not exempt from prescription charges, advise that it might be cheaper to buy proprietary flight socks over-the-counter.
  • Proprietary flight socks are widely available from pharmacies, airports, and many retail outlets.
    • They provide a compression of 14–17 mmHg at the ankle (equivalent to class 1 stockings). However, flight socks with higher ratings (18–21 mmHg, similar to class 2 stockings) are also available.
    • Stress the importance of ensuring that the socks are correctly fitted to provide adequate compression.
      • This is particularly important in people with varicose veins, in whom there may be an increased risk of superficial thrombophlebitis.
    • If in doubt, advise the person to seek advice from an appropriate healthcare professional (for example a pharmacist).
  • For further information on the use of compression stockings, see the CKS topic on Compression stockings.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the NHS Business Services Authority (NHSBSA) NHS electronic drug tariff [NHSBSA, 2018], and a randomized controlled trial Frequency and prevention of symptomless deep-vein thrombosis in long-haul flights [Scurr et al, 2001]. 

Varicose veins and increased risk of superficial thrombophlebitis
  • The recommendation to ensure stockings are correctly fitted is based on case reports of people with varicose veins developing superficial thrombophlebitis whilst wearing compression stockings during long-haul flights [Scurr et al, 2001].

subChapters.htmlHeader: Should I recommend aspirin for the prevention of travel-related deep vein thrombosis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Aspirin is not recommended for the prevention of travel-related deep vein thrombosis.
  • People already taking aspirin (for primary or secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease) should not increase their dose.
    • If low molecular weight heparin is prescribed, aspirin should not be discontinued without specialist advice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the World Health Organization (WHO) document International travel and health [WHO, 2012], the British Committee for Standards in Haematology (BCSH) Guidelines on travel-related venous thrombosis [Watson and Baglin, 2011], and the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) health information for travellers The yellow book: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism [CDC, 2017].

Use of low-dose aspirin
  • The WHO advises that as there is a clear risk of significant side effects and absence of clear evidence of benefit, and passengers should be advised not to use aspirin specifically for the prevention of travel-related deep vein thrombosis (DVT) [WHO, 2012].  
  • Where pharmacological prophylaxis is indicated, anticoagulants as opposed to antiplatelets are recommended based on the observation that in other clinical scenarios they provide more effective thromboprophylaxis [Watson and Baglin, 2011]. 
  • In cases where the potential benefits of pharmacologic prophylaxis outweigh the possible adverse effects, anticoagulants rather than antiplatelet drugs (such as aspirin) are recommended [CDC, 2017]. 
For people already prescribed aspirin for cardiovascular protection
  • The recommendation to advise people not to increase the dose of aspirin if they are already taking it for cardiovascular protection is pragmatic, as:
    • There is no clear evidence of benefit in taking aspirin for prevention of travel-related DVT.
    • Increasing the dose increases the risk of adverse effects.
    • The optimal dose range of aspirin for cardiovascular protection is 75–100 mg. For more information see the CKS topic on Antiplatelet treatment.
  • CKS found no guidance on managing low-dose aspirin therapy for these people if low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is indicated. Feedback from CKS expert reviewers generally indicated that aspirin for cardiovascular protection should be continued, taking into account the increased risk of bleeding. Consequently, CKS advises seeking specialist advice when LMWH is indicated for people prescribed aspirin for cardiovascular protection.
